BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. Natural moist avalanches are possible from the morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong adjacent to ridgelines in the regions that are exposed to the foehn wind. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as in high Alpine regions large wind slabs formed.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant and generally above the tree line.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation medium-sized to large gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected below approximately 2500 m. In the regions with a lot of snow and on wind-loaded slopes more large avalanches are possible, in particular in case of releases originating from starting zones that still retain some snow, caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as on extremely steep sunny slopes.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
At intermediate and high altitudes a very large amount of snow is lying.
In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In the last few days large and very large avalanches were observed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the near-surface layers during the night. From the late morning as the moisture increases there will be a gradual increase in the avalanche danger, caution is to be exercised in particular below very steep east, south and west facing starting zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A clear night will be followed in the early morning by sometimes favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase later.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A clear night will be followed in the early morning by sometimes favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase later.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. As the day progresses, dry and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a significant increase in the danger of dry and wet avalanches. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially in case of releases originating from very steep starting zones at intermediate and high altitudes that have retained the snow thus far.
Backcountry tours and off-piste skiing should be started and concluded early.
Slides can occur on cut slopes.
As a consequence of a strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence of these avalanche prone locations will increase from midday. They can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches in some places, including large ones.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Thursday: The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m.
Sunday: 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak in some cases. This applies in all aspects.
Today on very steep sunny slopes several medium-sized to large avalanches were observed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. As the day progresses, dry and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a significant increase in the danger of dry and wet avalanches. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially in case of releases originating from very steep starting zones at intermediate and high altitudes that have retained the snow thus far.
Backcountry tours and off-piste skiing should be started and concluded early.
Slides can occur on cut slopes.
As a consequence of a strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence of these avalanche prone locations will increase from midday. They can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches in some places, including large ones.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Thursday: The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m.
Sunday: 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak in some cases. This applies in all aspects.
Today on very steep sunny slopes several medium-sized to large avalanches were observed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days can still be released above the tree line. Natural moist avalanches are possible from the morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong at times in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as in high Alpine regions further wind slabs formed. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more medium-sized and large avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. The surface of the snowpack will soften earlier than the day before.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. Individual weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
In the last few days medium-sized to large avalanches were observed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. These weather conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the near-surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of dry and wet avalanches. Caution is to be exercised in particular below very steep, sunny starting zones that still retain some snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong over a wide area. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line rather small wind slabs formed. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m. In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more medium-sized and large avalanches are possible.
The surface of the snowpack will soften earlier than the day before. Backcountry tours should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying in all altitude zones. As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. The new snow of the weekend has settled to a large extent in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In the last few days medium-sized to large avalanches were observed. The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. As the day progresses, dry and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of dry and wet avalanches. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially in case of releases originating from very steep starting zones at high altitude.
Backcountry tours and off-piste skiing should be started and concluded early.

As a consequence of a strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed in the last two days in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence of these avalanche prone locations will increase from midday. They can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches in some places, including large ones.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Thursday: The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m.
Sunday: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak in some cases. This applies in all aspects.
Today on very steep sunny slopes several medium-sized to large avalanches were observed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1900 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was stronger than expected adjacent to ridgelines in all regions. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as in high Alpine regions deep wind slabs formed.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant and generally above the tree line.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected. In the regions with a lot of snow and on wind-loaded slopes more large avalanches are possible, in particular in case of releases originating from starting zones that still retain some snow, caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. In all aspects small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches are possible. Avalanches can as before be released, in particular by large loads.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1900 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was stronger than expected adjacent to ridgelines in all regions. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as in high Alpine regions deep wind slabs formed.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant and generally above the tree line.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected. In the regions with a lot of snow and on wind-loaded slopes more large avalanches are possible, in particular in case of releases originating from starting zones that still retain some snow, caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. In all aspects small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches are possible. Avalanches can as before be released, in particular by large loads.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases moist. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual, then as a consequence of solar radiation more, and in some cases even large, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases moist. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual, then as a consequence of solar radiation more, and in some cases even large, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In addition the wind slabs must be taken into account.
As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. Snow slides and natural avalanches are still possible. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain.
Avalanches can as before be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust. The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack. This applies in particular on sunny slopes. In some places wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In addition large wind slabs formed also adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Loose snow avalanches require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they will be mostly small.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular in the west 10 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack will settle in the course of the day. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack, especially on sunny slopes, and on shady slopes at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snow drift accumulations will stabilise. Gradual decrease in avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of dry and wet avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong at times. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain mostly shallow wind slabs formed. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2400 m.
Backcountry tours should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying in all altitude zones. The new snow of the weekend has settled to a large extent in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
The surface of the snowpack will soften earlier than the day before. The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In the last few days medium-sized to large avalanches were observed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. In all aspects small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches are possible. Avalanches can as before be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and older wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. The danger of moist snow slides and avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Below approximately 2600 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches, in particular on steep sunny slopes above the tree line, as well as on steep east, south and west facing slopes. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks. In the regions with a lot of snow dry slab avalanches are possible.
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days can be released, especially by large additional loads, in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. These can in isolated cases reach quite a large size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as in places that are protected from the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size during the last few days. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on soft layers above approximately 2200 m. The weather conditions gave rise to gradual settling of the snowpack.
In all regions below the tree line a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual decrease in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day. More gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible on Friday, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist avalanches will increase during the day. The fresh and older wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can reach medium size in some cases, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
The new snow and wind slabs of the weekend are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Avalanches can be triggered in near-surface layers and reach medium size in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as in places that are protected from the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate altitudes. In all regions below the tree line a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep, little used shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found also on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are difficult to recognise. Released avalanches and reports filed by observers confirm the unfavourable bonding of the snowpack. In addition as the day progresses in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation, an increasing number of loose snow avalanches are possible.

The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack, especially on sunny slopes, and on shady slopes at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snow drift accumulations will stabilise. Gradual decrease in avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger, in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can be released in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack, especially on sunny slopes, and on shady slopes at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snow drift accumulations will stabilise. Gradual decrease in avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a gradual weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a gradual weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls and on steep sunny slopes the danger of moist and wet avalanches is a little higher. This applies in particular on east, south and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1800 m only a little snow is lying. The fresh and older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. Further warming: These weather conditions will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on east, south and east facing slopes.
